instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1465: What is A1465? A1465 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2924, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00164, 820-3208, 820-3435..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET</SIGNAL> and my stupidity
threads.message:
Macbook air 2012 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, came with sporadical shutdown problem. After 3-5 minutes of high load, the laptop shuts down and then works 20-30 seconds till shutdown unless cooled for a while. Since CPU/GPU were under 60Â°C, i checked all voltages and some reset signals, on board and found funny slow linear voltage drop on <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET</SIGNAL>, changed batteries in my multimeter and immediately confirmed it with a brilliant solution by Dukefawks from this forum.
After i changed both caps, it started to work and here comes the stupid one.
To test the board with the battery i used <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> jumper near the wlan card. I was too stupid to check if there's something dangerous around it and i guess i shorted <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> with damn <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3HOT_CHRG_REG</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C7045</CAPACITOR> which is happened to be just near this jumper. IDK if apple considers electrical safety but although i feel retarded enough for my mistake, i found it rather funny that they put 8V hot power rail just in 2mm from the power jumper, without even putting some sort of compound or glue.
[ATTACH alt="Click image for larger version  Name:	openboardview_2018-06-<SIGNAL>14_20</SIGNAL>-32-14.png Views:	1 Size:	384.9 KB ID:	35811"]35811._xfImport[/ATTACH]
Pic 1. Apple trap for big tweezers in shaky hands. 

Now i'm having 1.7V on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>, Keyboard power button drops it to 1.3V, and, of course, shorting it to ground does not turn the laptop on anymore, it starts only if i plug the charger in.
I am really pissed off with my stupidity but i am asking for some help.
Unfortunately, it's not <CAPACITOR>C5734</CAPACITOR> shorting to ground.
However, i found that <RESISTOR>R5070</RESISTOR> is nearly 1kOhm (10kOhm in schematics) in circuit. Is that possible that on higher load SMD resistors melt to lower resistance? Should i start searching for a new SMC and <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>, or it simply shorts my PP3V42 rail instead of turning it on?

Also, note to self: check <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> area for high power rails before you take your dirty tweezers in hand.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET</SIGNAL> and my stupidity
threads.message: SMC is certainly dead to start with. Seeing that this board already has a shitty shutdown problem that could be many things I would not put any more time into this. RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET</SIGNAL> and my stupidity
threads.message: Yup, I've decided to order a new one since working board could be found for just ~100$ on ebay. I'm wondering how many times power issues ending up with SMC death. PC laptops are far more repairable in this sense - when IO chip dies, it is almost always available without donor board lottery and can be pre-programmed with Vertyanov jig just like a normal flash chip, so it's almost never a big deal. :)
